chapter.title: Goals
chapter.para: It is a primary goal of JBossWS to provide an implementation that is compatible with the emerging JAXRPC-2.0 specification. The goals stated in this section relate to the goals defined in the JAXRPC-2.0 specification and clarify those with respect to JBossWS where necessary.

JAXB With the release of JAXB 2.0 there is no reason to maintain two separate sets of XML mapping rules in the Java platform. JBossWS will delegate data binding-related tasks to the JAXB 2.0 specification that is being developed in parallel with JAX-RPC 2.0.
JAXB 2.0 will add support for Java to XML mapping, additional support for less used XML schema constructs, and provide bidirectional customization of Java XML data binding.
Pluggable data binding JBossWS will defer data binding to JAXB unless there is a data binding plugin provided. The idea is to optimize the data binding algorithm based on the nature of expected data.

SOAP 1.2 Whilst SOAP 1.1 is still widely deployed, it is expected that services will migrate to SOAP 1.2 now that it is a W3C Recommendation. JBossWS will add support for SOAP 1.2 whilst continuing support for SOAP 1.1.
WSDL 2.0 TheW3C is expected to progress WSDL 2.0 to Recommendation. JBossWS will add support for WSDL 2.0 whilst continuing support for WSDL 1.1.
WS-I Basic Profile 1.1 WS-I Basic Profile 1.1 is expected to supersede 1.0 during the lifetime of JAX-RPC 2.0. JBossWS will add support for the additional clarifications it provides.
Metadata Facility (JSR 175) JBossWS will make use of Java annotations to simplify the most common development scenarios for both clients and servers.
Web Services Metadata (JSR 181) JBossWS will align with and complement the annotations defined by JSR 181.

Enterprise Web Services (JSR 109) The JSR 109 defined jaxrpc-mapping-info deployment descriptor provides deployment time Java , WSDL mapping functionality. In conjunction with JSR 181, JBossWS will implement mapping functionality with development time Java annotations that control Java?WSDL mapping.
Asynchrony JBossWS will have support for client side asynchronous operations.

Non-HTTP Transports JBossWS will leverage the JBoss Remoting framework to improve the separation between the XML based RPC framework and the underlying transport mechanism to simplify use of JAX-RPC with non-HTTP transports.
Message Access JBossWS will simplify client and service access to the messages underlying an exchange.
